issues.description: The template defines addGuestStudents with the signature addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, boolean validateInput) while the problem statement and UML specify addGuestStudents(int): void and the solution implements addGuestStudents(int). This mismatch in parameters will confuse students about which method they should implement or test against. Students might implement the two-argument version (following the template) but automated tests and the exercise specification expect the single-argument variant, or they might add an overloaded single-argument method which makes the template's existing method misleading.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the template with the problem statement and solution by changing the template method signature to public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) (remove the boolean parameter). Alternatively, provide an overloaded single-argument addGuestStudents(int) that delegates to the two-argument version or vice-versa, but the simplest fix is to remove the extra parameter so the template matches the UML/spec and the solution.

issues.description: The problem statement (and the UML) specify a method addGuestStudents(int) that takes a single int parameter. The solution implements public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents). However, the template defines public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, boolean validateInput) — an extra boolean parameter. This mismatch in the method signature across artifacts creates a direct mapping confusion: students following the problem text will look for/implement a single-argument method, but the template provides a different signature, and automated tests (and the solution) expect the single-argument form.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template method signature match the problem statement and solution. Change the template to declare public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) (and implement it as in the solution). Alternatively, if validation is desired, provide an overload: keep public void addGuestStudents(int) in the template (and optionally add a separate private/public boolean-accepting variant that the single-arg method delegates to). This keeps the student-facing API consistent with the instructions and tests.
